felix3142 wrote:
> 
> 
> Hello,
> 
> we're going to establish unit-testing (basically for web applications)
> in our company. Because we don't want to change the whole programming
> paradigm to XP we rather want to use a test-last method in the
> beginning and then watch out for further steps.
> I'm now in the process of investigating the basic requirements and
> conditions.
> One question that occured is if it's possible to quantify the amount
> of extra time you need when using unit testing compared to the
> non-testing approach. I solely refer to the writing of unit tests.
> Later saving of time (by better code) shouldn't be considered. So
> what's your experience? Can anybody do a statement about time
> consumption of writing unit tests?

Many people have said "there is no clear answer", and I agree. Instead, 
let me offer you a few variables to consider when guessing about the 
time you'll need to write unit tests for code that already exists. 
You'll spend time on each of these things:

1. Learning how to write tests (the syntax of JUnit)
2. Learning when two different tests test the same thing, and deciding 
when to remove one.
3. Discovering why a test is difficult to write.
4. Changing the design of the code to make it possible to write a test.
5. Changing the design of the code to make it easier to write a test.
6. Deciding which parts of the system are most important to test first.
7. Deciding whether to remove code instead of testing it, because it 
seems that code is not in use.
8. Deciding whether to change the design of code because it would make 
tests easier to write.
9. Deciding whether to change the design of code because it would help 
avoid writing duplicate tests (tests that look the same, but test 
different layers of the application)
10. Becoming comfortable with the fact that the first test could take 2 
days to write, then the second one 1/2 day, then the third one 1 hour, 
then the rest 5 minutes each

There are more, but I hope this gives you some insight into why it's 
difficult to answer your question. All these costs can be quite high, 
depending on your people, the code and your current project plans.

Finally, let me share a story from my past. Readers here know the story 
well, so I will just give you the key points. I once wrote a component 
in Java in 3 months, and it didn't quite work. I rewrote it using JUnit, 
doing the best kind of test-driven development I knew how to do at the 
time. The second time, I spent about 150 hours, which would be perhaps 
2.5 weeks (I worked overtime back then). If I needed to do it now, I 
could probably do it in one week.

So here is a case of writing code in 3 months (probably 600 hours), 
spending at most 150 hours to test it (while learning how to write 
tests). I imagine that 150 hours to test 600 hours' worth of code is a 
good performance--it could have taken 1500 hours, if the codebase was 
bigger and more complex. This was Java code I wrote that integrated a 
third-party Java tool, so it was low complexity, overall.

I hope that helps you. Good luck.
